[SPELLING]: "ol" instead of "of" in "the outlines ol which"
[SYNTAX]: Extremely long, convoluted sentences (e.g., first paragraph)
[LEXICON]: Anachronistic terms ("bluetooth signal," "diagnostic tool") in historical context

[LOGIC]: Inconsistent inclusion of modern technology ("bluetooth," "diagnostic tool") in 1907 setting
[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transitions between descriptive geography and abrupt tech references

[SYNTAX]: Awkward phrasing (e.g., "used by the Chinese as thimbles").
[GRAMMAR]: Minor subject-verb agreement (e.g., "better quality than is usually to be bought").

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt topic shifts (e.g., house → clothing → crafts).
[TRANSITION]: Lack of connecting phrases between paragraphs.
[LOGIC]: Repetitive or tangential details (e.g., "nothing new is bought").
